The **PlayStation Vita** (**PS Vita**, or **Vita**) is a [game console](handheld)(handheld game console) developed and marketed by [Interactive Entertainment](Sony)(Sony Interactive Entertainment). It was first released in [Japan](Japan) on December 17, 2011, and in [America](North)(North America), [Europe](Europe), and other international territories beginning on February 22, 2012. The console is the successor to the [Portable](PlayStation)(PlayStation Portable), and a part of the [PlayStation](PlayStation) brand of gaming devices; as part of the [generation of video game consoles](eighth)(eighth generation of video game consoles), it primarily competed with the [3DS](Nintendo)(Nintendo 3DS).

The original model of the handheld includes a  [OLED](OLED) multi-touch [touchscreen](capacitive)(capacitive touchscreen), two [joysticks](analog)(analog stick), and front and shoulder [push-button](push-button) input, and supports [Bluetooth](Bluetooth v2.1+EDR), [Wi-Fi](Wi-Fi), and optional [3G](3G). The Vita features a quad-core [Cortex-A9 MPCore](ARM)(ARM Cortex-A9 MPCore) CPU and a quad-core [SGX543MP](PowerVR SGXMP) GPU. The PS Vita 2000 series, a revised version of the system, was released across 2013 and 2014. It has all of the same features with a slightly smaller size, extended battery life, and an [LCD](LCD) screen instead of OLED. Sony released the [TV](PlayStation)(PlayStation TV), a short-lived, re-purposed version of the Vita that uses a [television](television) screen like a [video game console](home)(home video game console), discontinued at the end of 2015.

The Vita's design was intended to meld the experience of big-budget, dedicated [game platforms](video)(video game platforms) with the then up-and-coming trend of [gaming](mobile)(mobile gaming) as seen on [phones](smart)(smart phones) and [tablets](tablet computer). However, in the year after the device's successful launch, sales of the hardware and its bigger budget games stalled, threatening to end its lifespan. A concentrated effort to attract smaller independent developers in the West, combined with strong support from mid-level Japanese companies, helped keep the platform afloat. Though this led to less diversity in its game library, it strengthened support in [JRPG](JRPG)s, [novels](visual)(visual novels), and Western-developed [games](indie)(indie games). This built moderate sales in Japan and a smaller yet passionate userbase in the West. Though Sony has not released exact sales figures, estimates are around 15 to 16 million units. In the platform's later years, Sony promoted the PlayStation Vita's ability to work in conjunction with its other gaming products, such as [Play](Remote)(Remote Play) of [4](PlayStation)(PlayStation 4) games, similar to the [U](Wii)(Wii U)'s function of [Play](Off-TV)(Off-TV Play).

The platform stalled in 2017 upon the release of the [Switch](Nintendo)(Nintendo Switch), and was completely discontinued in 2019. The system is regarded as a [failure in the video game industry](commercial)(List of commercial failures in video games), and was significantly outsold by the Nintendo 3DS. No direct successor was released by Sony, though in 2023, a similar remote play accessory, [Q](Project)(Project Q (PlayStation 5)), was announced for release by the end of the year for the [5](PlayStation)(PlayStation 5).
## History

### Background

After the success of [Nintendo](Nintendo)'s [Boy family](Game)(Game Boy family) of [game console](handheld)(handheld game console)s throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, with little market competition, and [Sony](Sony)'s massive success with its [PlayStation](PlayStation (console)) and [2](PlayStation)(PlayStation 2) [video game console](home)(home video game console)s around the same time, Sony entered the handheld market as well. In 2004, it released the [Portable](PlayStation)(PlayStation Portable) (PSP) to compete with the [DS](Nintendo)(Nintendo DS) as part of the [generation of video game consoles](seventh)(seventh generation of video game consoles). After a slow start in the worldwide market, it was invigorated in Japan with multiple releases in the *[Hunter](Monster)(Monster Hunter)* series. With the series being less popular in western regions, it failed to revive the platform in the same way. The PSP ended up being a mixed result for the company. It was seen as a success in that it was the only handheld video game platform that had ever significantly competed with Nintendo for market share, with almost 80 million units sold in its lifespan, roughly the same amount as Nintendo's [Boy Advance](Game)(Game Boy Advance) had during the [generation of video game consoles](sixth)(sixth generation of video game consoles). This is only a little more than half of the sales of its actual market competitor, the DS, which was more than 150 million units by the end of 2011.

Rumors of a successor to the PSP came as early as July 2009 when *[Eurogamer](Eurogamer)* reported that Sony was working on such a device, which would utilize the PowerVR SGX543MP processor and perform at a level similar to the original [Xbox](Xbox (console)). Through mid-2010, websites continued to run stories about accounts of the existence of a "PSP 2". Reports arose during the [Game Show](Tokyo)(Tokyo Game Show) that the device was unveiled internally during a private meeting during mid-September held at Sony Computer Entertainment's headquarters in Aoyama, Tokyo. Shortly after, reports of [kits](development)(development kits) for the handheld had reportedly already been shipped to numerous video game developers including both [first-party](SIE Worldwide Studios) and third-party developers to start making games for the device, a report later confirmed by *[Kombat](Mortal)(Mortal Kombat (2011 video game))* Executive Producer Shaun Himmerick. By November, Senior Vice President of [Arts](Electronic)(Electronic Arts), Patrick Soderlund, confirmed that he had seen that the PlayStation Portable successor existed, but could not confirm details. In the same month, [VG247](VG247) released pictures of an early prototype version showing a [Go](PSP)(PSP Go)-like slide-screen design along with two analog sticks, two cameras and a microphone, though the report mentioned that overheating issues had since caused them to move away from the design in favor of a model more similar to the original PlayStation Portable device.

Throughout 2010, Sony would not confirm these reports of a PSP successor but would make comments regarding making future hardware. [Yoshida](Shuhei)(Shuhei Yoshida), President of [Worldwide Studios](SCE)(SCE Worldwide Studios) revealed that his studio, despite usually being more involved with software, had a continued role in future hardware development at the time. In December, [Computer Entertainment](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment) CEO [Hirai](Kazuo)(Kazuo Hirai) stated that Sony aimed to appeal to a wide demographic of people by using multiple input methods on future hardware; buttons and joysticks for traditional handheld game system users, and touchscreens for [phone](smart)(smart phone) users. The device was officially announced by Sony on January 27, 2011, at their "PlayStation Meeting" press conference held by the company in Japan. The system, only known by its code name "Next Generation Portable", was announced to be a handheld gaming device that aimed for [3](PlayStation)(PlayStation 3) quality visuals, which was later clarified to not be taken at a literal level because, according to David Coombes, platform research manager at [Computer Entertainment America](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment America), "Well, it's not going to run at 2 GHz [the PS3](like) because the battery would last five minutes and it would probably set fire to your pants". Its power was later described by Sony engineers as about halfway between the PSP and PS3. As rumors had suggested, the device was designed to present "the best of both worlds" between mobile and handheld gaming, including a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, a rear touchpad coupled with physical buttons and dual analog sticks. Sony also revealed that the device would be using a mix of retail and digital distribution of games. Further details were announced at [Developers Conference](Game)(Game Developers Conference) 2011, including that Sony would be dropping the PSP's [UMD](Universal Media Disc) disc format in favor of small game cartridges of 2 GB or 4 GB size variants.  along with two cameras, facial detection, head detection and tracking capabilities.
Next Generation Portable (NGP).

***Twisters*** is an upcoming American [epic](epic film) [film](disaster)(disaster film) directed by [Isaac Chung](Lee)(Lee Isaac Chung) from a screenplay by [L. Smith](Mark)(Mark L. Smith). Produced by [Marshall](Frank)(Frank Marshall (filmmaker)), it is described as a "new chapter" of the 1996 film *[Twister](Twister (1996 film))* and stars [Edgar-Jones](Daisy)(Daisy Edgar-Jones), [Powell](Glen)(Glen Powell) and [Ramos](Anthony)(Anthony Ramos). The film is scheduled to be released by [Pictures](Universal)(Universal Pictures) in the United States and by [Bros. Pictures](Warner)(Warner Bros. Pictures) internationally on July 19, 2024.
Universal Pictures will distribute Twisters in the United States, and Warner Bros. Pictures will distribute it internationally.

# Doctor Octopus

*Revision ID: 1159567160 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T04:52:05Z*

---

}}

**Doctor Octopus** (**Dr. Otto Gunther Octavius**), also known as **Doc Ock** for short, is a fictional character appearing in [comic book](American)(American comic book)s published by [Comics](Marvel)(Marvel Comics). The character was created by [Lee](Stan)(Stan Lee) and [Ditko](Steve)(Steve Ditko) and first appeared in *[Amazing Spider-Man](The)(The Amazing Spider-Man)* #3 (July 1963). He is a highly intelligent, [myopic](Near-sightedness), and somewhat stocky [scientist](mad)(mad scientist) who sports four strong and durable appendages resembling an [octopus](octopus)'s tentacles, which extend from the back of his body and can be used for various purposes. After his mechanical harness became permanently fused to his body during a lab accident, he turned to a life of crime, and came into conflict with the [superhero](superhero) [Spider-Man](Spider-Man). He has endured as one of Spider-Man's most prominent villains, and is regarded as one of his three [archenemies](Archenemy), alongside the [Goblin](Green)(Norman Osborn) and [Venom](Venom (Marvel Comics character)). He is the founder and leader of the [Six](Sinister)(Sinister Six), the first [supervillain](supervillain) team to oppose Spider-Man.

While usually portrayed as a [supervillain](supervillain), Doctor Octopus has also been occasionally depicted as a conflicted [antihero](antihero) and ally of Spider-Man. Following Spider-Man's death in the 2012 storyline "[Wish](Dying)(Dying Wish)", which saw a dying Octavius swapping bodies with the hero and letting him die in his original body, Octavius was motivated to prove he could be a better Spider-Man. As such, he adopted the **Superior Spider-Man** alias, introduced in *[Spider-Man](Avenging)(Avenging Spider-Man)* #15.1 following a cameo in *[Daredevil](Daredevil (Marvel Comics series))* vol. 3 #21 (both December 2012). The Superior Spider-Man possesses all of the original Spider-Man's abilities, memories, and equipment, along with additional gadgets created by Octavius, though he often struggles to live up to his predecessor's legacy and seeks to turn his life around after being a villain for years. In 2013, Marvel launched a 45-issue *[Superior Spider-Man](The)(The Superior Spider-Man)* comic book series focusing on the character's redemption and superhero career. The original Spider-Man has since been resurrected after the death of Otto Octavius. Following *[Spider-Verse](Spider-Verse)*, a copy of his consciousness became a villain, though a second volume of *The Superior Spider-Man* launched in 2018 saw the duplicate taking on the mantle before returning to the Doctor Octopus mantle as an [antihero](antihero), having his soul restored and memories of redemption erased by [Mephisto](Mephisto (Marvel Comics)), before returning to the role of Superior Spider-Man in 2023 in a new series by [Slott](Dan)(Dan Slott).

Comics journalist and historian [Conroy](Mike)(Mike Conroy (writer)) writes of the character: "Created by [Lee](Stan)(Stan Lee) and artist [Ditko](Steve)(Steve Ditko), Doc Ock, as he became known, has become one of the web-slinger's most persistent, enduring, and dangerous foes."[Mike](Conroy,)(Mike Conroy (writer)). 500 Comicbook Villains, p.44-45, Collins & Brown, 2004. A fan favorite character and well-known figure in [culture](popular)(popular culture), Doctor Octopus has been featured in various media adaptations of Spider-Man over the years, including feature films, television series, and video games. [Molina](Alfred)(Alfred Molina) portrayed [character](the)(Otto Octavius (film character)) in the films *[2](Spider-Man)(Spider-Man 2)* (2004) and *[No Way Home](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: No Way Home)* (2021). In the animated *Spider-Verse* films, [Hahn](Kathryn)(Kathryn Hahn) voiced a female version of Doctor Octopus named Olivia Octavius in *[Into the Spider-Verse](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse)* (2018), while an alternate Otto Octavius as the Superior Spider-Man appears in its sequel, *[Across the Spider-Verse](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse)* (2023), in which Molina appearing via archive audio. [Salyers](William)(William Salyers) voices the character in the ''[Spider-Man](Marvel's)(Spider-Man (Insomniac Games series))* video game series and *[Ultimate Alliance 3: The Black Order](Marvel)(Marvel Ultimate Alliance 3: The Black Order)* (2019).

In 2009, *[IGN](IGN)'' ranked Doctor Octopus 28th in the Top 100 Comic Book Villains of All Time, and in 2014 rated him Spider-Man's greatest enemy.
Doctor Otto Octavius (Doctor Octopus), often called Doc Ock.

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.
It is a specific instance of the general hexagram shape discussed in Pascal's Mysticum Hexagrammum Mysticum (Hexagrammum Mysticum).

### Contemporary regulations

[[sign warning about the presence of bears. The Norwegian text translates into "Applies to all of Svalbard".](File:Polar-Bear-Warning-Longyearbyen.jpg|thumb|right|Road)]

Concerns over the future survival of the species led to the development of national regulations on polar bear hunting, beginning in the mid-1950s. The Soviet Union banned all hunting in 1956. Canada began imposing hunting quotas in 1968. Norway passed a series of increasingly strict regulations from 1965 to 1973, and has completely banned hunting since then. The United States began regulating hunting in 1971 and adopted the [Mammal Protection Act](Marine)(Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972) in 1972. In 1973, the [Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](International)(International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears) was signed by all five nations whose territory is inhabited by polar bears: Canada, Denmark, Norway, the [Union](Soviet)(Soviet Union), and the United States. Member countries agreed to place restrictions on recreational and commercial hunting, ban hunting from aircraft and icebreakers, and conduct further research.[International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](https://web.archive.org/web/20030409113042/http://pbsg.npolar.no/ConvAgree/agreement.htm), 15 November 1973, Oslo The treaty allows hunting "by local people using traditional methods". Norway is the only country of the five in which all harvest of polar bears is banned. The agreement was a rare case of international cooperation during the [War](Cold)(Cold War). Biologist [Stirling](Ian)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) commented, "For many years, the conservation of polar bears was the only subject in the entire Arctic that nations from both sides of the Iron Curtain could agree upon sufficiently to sign an agreement. Such was the intensity of human fascination with this magnificent predator, the only marine bear."[Ian](Stirling,)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) *Foreword* in

Agreements have been made between countries to co-manage their shared polar bear subpopulations. After several years of negotiations, Russia and the United States signed an agreement in October 2000 to jointly set quotas for indigenous subsistence hunting in Alaska and [Chukotka](Chukotka Autonomous Okrug). The treaty was ratified in October 2007. In September 2015, the polar bear range states agreed upon a "circumpolar action plan" describing their conservation strategy for polar bears.

The species is listed in Appendix II of the [on International Trade in Endangered Species](Convention)(Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species) (CITES) meaning international trade, including in parts or derivatives, is controlled by the CITES system of permits and certificates. The United States government has proposed that polar bears be transferred to Appendix I of [CITES](CITES) which would ban all commercial international trade in polar bear parts. The decision to leave the species listed under Appendix II was endorsed by the IUCN and [TRAFFIC](TRAFFIC), who determined that such an uplisting was unlikely to confer a conservation benefit.
Canada, Denmark, Norway, the Soviet Union, and the United States. (Denmark includes Greenland; the Soviet Union is the historical signatory, with Russia as its successor.)

### Later life

[[File:Miyamoto Musashi Self-Portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Miyamoto Musashi, *[Self-portrait](Self-portrait),* c. 1640]]Twenty-one years later, in 1633, Musashi began staying with [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi), *[daimyō](Daimyo)* of [Castle](Kumamoto)(Kumamoto Castle), who had moved to the [Kumamoto](Kumamoto) fief and Kokura, to train and paint. While he engaged in very few duels; one would occur in 1634 at the arrangement of Lord Ogasawara, in which Musashi defeated a lance specialist by the name of [Matabei](Takada)(Takada Matabei). Musashi would officially become the retainer of the Hosokowa lords of Kumamoto in 1640. The *Niten Ki* records "[he] received from Lord Tadatoshi: 17 retainers, a stipend of 300 [koku](koku), the rank of *ōkumigashira* 大組頭, and [Castle](Chiba)(Chiba Castle) in Kumamoto as his residence."Toyota, p. 250

[[File:Tombe de Miyamoto Musashi à Ōhara, province de Mimasaka.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi's grave in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama), [of Mimasaka](province)(Mimasaka Province)]]

[[park.JPG|thumb|upright|The grave-marker of Miyamoto Musashi, in present-day Kumamoto Prefecture (熊本県)](File:Musashizuka)]

[[File:Miyamoto_Musashi_killing_a_giant_nue.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi kills a shark fish (Yamazame) in the mountains across the border of [Province](Echizen)(Echizen Province), by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

[[File:Musashi_ts_pic.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi in his prime, wielding two [bokken](bokken); woodblock print by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

In the second month of 1641, Musashi wrote a work called the *Hyoho Sanju Go* ("Thirty-five Instructions on Strategy") for [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi). This work overlapped and formed the basis for the later *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. This was the year that his adopted son, [Yoemon](Hirao)(Hirao Yoemon), became Master of Arms for the Owari fief. In 1642, Musashi suffered attacks of [neuralgia](neuralgia), foreshadowing his future ill-health. In 1643 he retired to a cave named *[Reigandō](Reigandō)* as a hermit to write *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. He finished it in the second month of 1645. On the twelfth of the fifth month, sensing his impending death, Musashi bequeathed his worldly possessions, after giving his manuscript copy of *The Book of Five Rings* to the younger brother of Terao Magonojo, his closest disciple. He died in Reigandō cave around June 13, 1645 (*[Shōhō](Shōhō) 2, 19th day of the 5th month*). The *Hyoho senshi denki* described his passing:

Miyamoto Musashi died of what is believed to be [cancer](thoracic)(lung cancer). He died peacefully after finishing the text *[Dokkōdō](Dokkōdō)* ("The Way of Walking Alone", or "The Way of Self-Reliance"), 21 precepts on self-discipline to guide future generations.
Believed to be lung cancer. He died in the Reigandō cave around June 1645.

## Ships

[[File:Ships in Bombay Harbour, 1731.jpg|thumb|right|Ships in [Harbour](Bombay)(Bombay Harbour), c. 1731]]

Ships of the East India Company were called [Indiamen](East)(East Indiaman) or simply "Indiamen".Sutton, Jean (1981) *Lords of the East: The East India Company and Its Ships*. London: Conway Maritime Their names were sometimes prefixed with the initials "HCS", standing for "Honourable Company's Service" or "Honourable Company's Ship", such as  and .

[[Royal George.jpg|thumb|right| was one of the five East Indiamen the Spanish fleet captured in 1780](File:Indiaman)]

During the [Revolutionary](French)(French Revolutionary Wars) and [Wars](Napoleonic)(Napoleonic Wars), the East India Company arranged for [of marque](letters)(Letter of marque) for its vessels such as *Lord Nelson*. This was not so that they could carry cannon to fend off warships, privateers, and pirates on their voyages to India and China (that they could do without permission) but so that, should they have the opportunity to take a prize, they could do so without being guilty of piracy. Similarly, the *Earl of Mornington*, an East India Company [ship](packet)(packet ship) of only six guns, also sailed under a letter of marque.

In addition, the company had its own navy, the [Marine](Bombay)(History of the Indian Navy), equipped with warships such as . These vessels often accompanied vessels of the Royal Navy on expeditions, such as the [of Java](Invasion)(Invasion of Java (1811)).

At the [of Pulo Aura](Battle)(Battle of Pulo Aura), which was probably the company's most notable naval victory, [Dance](Nathaniel)(Nathaniel Dance), Commodore of a convoy of Indiamen and sailing aboard the , led several Indiamen in a skirmish with a French squadron, driving them off. Some six years earlier, on 28 January 1797, five Indiamen, *Woodford*, under Captain Charles Lennox, *Taunton-Castle*, Captain Edward Studd, *Canton*, Captain Abel Vyvyan, *Boddam*, Captain George Palmer, and , Captain John Christian Lochner, had encountered Admiral [Sercey](de)(Pierre César Charles de Sercey) and his squadron of frigates. On this occasion the Indiamen succeeded in bluffing their way to safety, and without any shots even being fired. Lastly, on 15 June 1795, *General Goddard* played a large role in the capture of seven Dutch East Indiamen off [Helena](St)(Saint Helena).

[Indiamen](East)(East Indiamen) were large and strongly built and when the [Navy](Royal)(Royal Navy) was desperate for vessels to escort merchant convoys it bought several of them to convert to warships. *Earl of Mornington* became HMS *Drake*. Other examples include:

*

*

*  (1795)

*  (1804)

*

*

Their design as merchant vessels meant that their performance in the warship role was underwhelming and the Navy converted them to transports.
Indiamen — commonly called East Indiamen.

## Etymology

[[van Strij - Het Jacht van de kamer Rotterdam.jpg|thumb|An 18th-century Dutch *jacht*](File:Jacob)]

The term, *yacht*, originates from the [Dutch](Dutch language) word *jacht* (pl. *jachten*, which means "hunt"), and originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels that the [Republic](Dutch)(Dutch Republic) navy used to pursue [pirate](pirate)s and other transgressors around and into the shallow waters of the [Countries](Low)(Low Countries).

The word yacht comes from the Dutch word jacht (plural jachten), meaning "hunt." It originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels used by the Dutch navy to chase pirates and other transgressors in the shallow waters around the Low Countries; the term was later adopted into English to describe fast, graceful vessels (and eventually pleasure boats).

## Military career

### Political crisis in Scotland

[[edinburghcastle.jpg|thumb|left|Statue of Wallace at Edinburgh Castle](File:Braveheart)]

When Wallace was growing up, King [III](Alexander)(Alexander III of Scotland) ruled Scotland. His reign had seen a period of peace and economic stability. On 19 March 1286, however, Alexander died after falling from his horse.Traquair p. 15 The heir to the throne was Alexander's granddaughter, [Maid of Norway](Margaret,)(Margaret, Maid of Norway). As she was still a child and in Norway, the Scottish lords set up a government of guardians. Margaret fell ill on the voyage to Scotland and died in Orkney in late September 1290. The lack of a clear heir led to a period known as the "Great Cause", with a total of thirteen contenders laying claim to the throne. The most credible claims were [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) and [Bruce](Robert)(Robert Bruce, 5th Lord of Annandale), grandfather of the future king [the Bruce](Robert)(Robert the Bruce).Traquair pp. 23–35

With Scotland threatening to descend into civil war, King [I of England](Edward)(Edward I of England) was invited in by the Scottish nobility to arbitrate. Before the process could begin, he insisted that all of the contenders recognise him as [Paramount of Scotland](Lord)(Lord Paramount of Scotland). In early November 1292, at a great feudal court held in the castle at [Berwick-upon-Tweed](Berwick-upon-Tweed), judgment was given in favour of [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) having the strongest claim in law based on being senior in genealogical [primogeniture](primogeniture) even though not in [of blood](proximity)(proximity of blood).

Edward proceeded to take steps to progressively undermine John's authority, treating [Scotland](Scotland) as a feudal vassal state, demanding [homage](Homage (feudal)) be paid towards himself and military support in his war against France — even summoning King John Balliol to stand before the English court as a common plaintiff. The Scots soon tired of their deeply compromised king, and the direction of affairs was allegedly taken out of his hands by the leading men of the kingdom, who appointed a Council of Twelve—in practice, a new panel of Guardians—at [Stirling](Stirling) in July 1295. They went on to conclude a treaty of mutual assistance with France—known in later years as the [Alliance](Auld)(Auld Alliance).

In retaliation for Scotland's treaty with France, Edward I invaded, storming Berwick-upon-Tweed and commencing the [of Scottish Independence](Wars)(Wars of Scottish Independence). The Scots were defeated at [Dunbar](Battle of Dunbar (1296)) and the English took [Castle](Dunbar)(Dunbar Castle) on 27 April 1296. Edward forced John to abdicate, which he did at [Stracathro](Stracathro) near [Montrose](Montrose, Angus) on 10 July 1296.Dunbar, Sir Archibald H., Bt., *Scottish Kings – A Revised Chronology of Scottish History 1005–1625*, Edinburgh, 1899: p. 116 Here the arms of Scotland were formally torn from John's surcoat, giving him the abiding name of "Toom Tabard" (empty coat). By July, Edward had instructed his officers to receive formal homage from some 1,800 Scottish nobles (many of the rest being prisoners of war at that time).Traquair pp. 15–59

### Start of the uprising

[[File:William Wallace statue, Scottish National Portrait Gallery, Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|upright|Wallace statue by D. W. Stevenson on the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, [Edinburgh](Edinburgh)]]

The first act definitely known to have been carried out by Wallace was his [of William de Heselrig](killing)(Action at Lanark), the English High Sheriff of Lanark, in May 1297. He then joined with [the Hardy, Lord of Douglas](William)(William the Hardy, Lord of Douglas), and they carried out the [of Scone](raid)(raid of Scone). This was one of several rebellions taking place across Scotland, including those of several Scottish nobles and [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray) in the north.Traquair pp.63–67

The uprising suffered a blow when the nobles submitted to the English at [Irvine](Irvine, Scotland) in July. Wallace and Moray were not involved, and continued their rebellions. Wallace used the [Forest](Ettrick)(Selkirkshire) as a base for raiding, and attacked [Wishart](Robert Wishart)'s palace at [Ancrum](Ancrum). Wallace and Moray met and joined their forces, possibly at the siege of Dundee in early September.Traquair pp. 70–73

#### Battle of Stirling Bridge

[[Bridge.jpg|thumb|left|The later Stirling Bridge](File:Stirling)]

On 11 September 1297, an army jointly led by Wallace and [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray) won the [of Stirling Bridge](Battle)(Battle of Stirling Bridge). Although vastly outnumbered, the Scottish army routed the English army. [de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey](John)(John de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey)'s feudal army of 3,000 cavalry and 8,000 to 10,000 infantry met disaster as they crossed over to the north side of the river. The narrowness of the bridge prevented many soldiers from crossing together (possibly as few as three men abreast), so, while the English soldiers crossed, the Scots held back until half of them had passed and then killed the English as quickly as they could cross. The infantry were sent on first, followed by heavy cavalry. The Scots' [schiltron](schiltron) formations forced the infantry back into the advancing cavalry. A pivotal charge, led by one of Wallace's captains, caused some of the English soldiers to retreat as others pushed forward, and under the overwhelming weight, the bridge collapsed and many English soldiers drowned. Thus, the Scots won a significant victory, boosting the confidence of their army. [de Cressingham](Hugh)(Hugh de Cressingham), Edward's treasurer in Scotland, died in the fighting and it is reputed that his body was subsequently flayed and the skin cut into small pieces as tokens of the victory. The Lanercost Chronicle records that Wallace had "a broad strip [Cressingham's skin](of) ... taken from the head to the heel, to make therewith a [baldric](baldric)k for his sword".*Chronicle of Lanercost*, ed. H. Maxwell, vol. 1, p. 164.Traquair, p. 76

After the battle, Moray and Wallace assumed the title of Guardians of the Kingdom of Scotland on behalf of King [Balliol](John)(John Balliol). Moray died of wounds suffered on the battlefield sometime in late 1297.

Around November 1297, Wallace led a large-scale raid into northern England, through Northumberland and Cumberland.Traquair pp. 77–79

In a ceremony, at the 'Kirk o' the Forest' ([Selkirk](Selkirk, Scottish Borders)), towards the end of the year, Wallace was [knight](knight)ed. This would have been carried out by one of three Scottish earls—[Carrick](Robert the Bruce), [Strathearn](Maol Íosa III, Earl of Strathearn) or [Lennox](Maol Choluim I, Earl of Lennox).Traquair p. 79[John](Prebble,)(John Prebble) *The Lion in the North*
## Military career
He was one of the Guardians of the Kingdom of Scotland (a joint Guardian with Andrew Moray after the Stirling Bridge uprising in September 1297, continuing as Guardian into 1298).

## Television, film, and pop culture

Over the years, List and his crimes have furnished inspiration for documentaries, television dramas and feature films. Examples include "Savior," the season 6, episode 16 of the television series *[& Order](Law)(Law & Order)*; the 1987 film *[Stepfather](The)(The Stepfather (1987 film))* and its [remake](2009)(The Stepfather (2009 film)); the 1993 film *[Day: The John List Story](Judgment)(Judgment Day: The John List Story)*, in which List was portrayed by [Blake](Robert)(Robert Blake (actor)); and the character [Söze](Keyser)(Keyser Söze) in the 1995 film *[Usual Suspects](The)(The Usual Suspects)*.*The Usual Suspects* DVD commentary featuring [Singer](Bryan)(Bryan Singer) and [McQuarrie](Christopher)(Christopher McQuarrie), [2000]. Retrieved September 27, 2002.

In 2008, [Walsh](John)(John Walsh (television host)), the host of ''America's Most Wanted'', donated the age-progressed bust by Frank Bender that played a pivotal role in List's apprehension to a forensic science exhibit at the [Museum of Crime & Punishment](National)(National Museum of Crime & Punishment) in [D.C.](Washington,)(Washington, D.C.), whose collection was later moved to [East](Alcatraz)(Alcatraz East) Crime Museum in [Forge, Tennessee](Pigeon)(Pigeon Forge, Tennessee).

A 1996 episode of the series *[Files](Forensic)(Forensic Files)* discussed the List murders. A 2003 episode of the [A&E](A&E (TV channel)) series *[Justice](American)(American Justice)* also detailed the case and featured an interview with List. In 2015, the story was covered in the season 2, episode 2 of the [Discovery](Investigation)(Investigation Discovery) TV series *[Worst Nightmare](Your)(Your Worst Nightmare)*. The episode, "Murder House", premiered on November 18, 2015.

The movie *A Killer Next Door*, based on the events that led to the capture of John List, was released In July 2020.

In 2022, NJ Advance Media released "Father Wants Us Dead," a podcast serial on the events.

Also in 2022, [Netflix](Netflix) released a seven-part dramatic fictional miniseries called *[Watcher](The)(The Watcher (2022 TV series))*. Although it is a work of fiction, much of the character John Graff was borrowed from the story of the John List murders.Nolfi, Joey (2022-10-14). ["The Watcher's Grisly John Graff Murder Sequence Is Based on True Story of a Family Massacre."](https://ew.com/tv/the-watcher-john-graff-true-story-john-list-family-murders/) *[Weekly](Entertainment)(Entertainment Weekly)*. Retrieved 2022-10-20.  Played by [Mantello](Joe)(Joe Mantello), much of John Graff's story was identical such as his being an accountant, attending a Lutheran church, and murdering his family members and live-in mother, along with leaving music playing in the house and planning an alibi that would cause the bodies to remain undiscovered for several weeks.

John List Society are a band from Atlanta, GA who play "Punk / hardcore songs about serial killers" https://www.instagram.com/johnlistsociety/

### Early career

Vingegaard was born and raised in [Thy](Thy (district)). He played both [football](association football) and [handball](handball) from an early age. Vingegaard was a spectator, alongside his father, when the first stage of [Danmark Rundt](2007)(2007 Danmark Rundt) departed on 1 August from [Thisted](Thisted), the main town in the region. At the race, local cycling club Thy Cykle Ring had set up a home trainer so audience members could see what it was like to cycle up a mountain. He subsequently enrolled in the club and started riding his first races. He cycled with the Thy Cykle Ring for five seasons, until he moved to Aalborg Cykle Ring in 2013. In 2014, his last year as a junior rider, Vingegaard joined Odder Cykel Klub. When he became a senior rider, he initially struggled and performed poorly in races. When Odder Cykel Club established a U23 team from the start of 2016, results improved for Vingegaard. In the spring, he finished on the podium at a race in [Aalborg](Aalborg), and in May, he won a section of Pinse Cuppen in [Hammel](Hammel), where the riders had to climb the famed local hill Pøt Mølle several times.

**Accenture plc** is an Irish-American [services](professional)(professional services) company [in Dublin](based)(Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland), specializing in [technology](information)(information technology) (IT) services and [consulting](Management consulting). A [Global 500](*Fortune*)(Fortune Global 500) company, it reported revenues of $61.6 billion in 2022. Accenture's current clients include 91 of the *Fortune* Global 100 and more than three-quarters of the *Fortune* Global 500. , Accenture is considered the largest consulting firm in the world by number of employees.

[Sweet](Julie)(Julie Sweet) has served as CEO of Accenture since 1 September 2019. ## Etymology

The term *Khmers rouges*, [French](French language) for [red](Political colour#Red) [Khmers](Khmer people), was coined by King Norodom Sihanouk and later adopted by English speakers (in the form of the corrupted version Khmer Rouge). It was used to refer to a succession of communist parties in Cambodia which evolved into the Communist Party of Kampuchea and later the [of Democratic Kampuchea](Party)(Party of Democratic Kampuchea). Its military was known successively as the [Revolutionary Army](Kampuchean)(Kampuchean Revolutionary Army) and the [Army of Democratic Kampuchea](National)(National Army of Democratic Kampuchea).

Since the serious deterioration in relations between [Republic of Vietnam](Socialist)(Socialist Republic of Vietnam) and [Kampuchea](Democratic)(Democratic Kampuchea), the [communism](Vietnamese)(Communist Party of Vietnam) authority no longer recognize the legitimacy of Khmer Rouge, and calls it **Pol Pot-Ieng Sary group** () or **Pol Pot-Ieng Sary reactionary group** ().
Norodom Sihanouk.

## Early life

Kiernan Brennan Shipka was born in [Chicago](Chicago), [Illinois](Illinois), to John Young Shipka, a real estate developer, and Erin Ann Brennan. Shipka started taking [dancing](ballroom)(ballroom dancing) classes at the age of five, and was still attending classes as of March 2012. Her family relocated to [Angeles](Los)(Los Angeles), [California](California) when she was six to help with her acting career.
She started ballroom dancing classes at the age of five.

## Early life

He was born Alfredo Molina on 24 May 1953 in the [Paddington](Paddington) district of London. His father, Esteban J. Molina, was a Spanish immigrant from [Murcia](Murcia), who came to England in 1939, and worked as a waiter and chauffeur. His mother, Giovanna (née Bonelli), was an Italian immigrant who moved to Britain after [War II](World)(World War II), and who cleaned rooms in a hotel, and worked as a cook and housekeeper. Molina grew up in a working-class district in [Hill](Notting)(Notting Hill) that was inhabited by many other immigrant families. He attended a Roman Catholic secondary school there. He decided to become an actor after seeing *[Spartacus](Spartacus (film))* at the age of nine, and attended the [School of Music and Drama](Guildhall)(Guildhall School of Music and Drama), as well as auditioning for and becoming a member of the [Youth Theatre](National)(National Youth Theatre). At the age of 21, he changed his name to Alfred, at the urging of his first agent.
The Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London.

# Rock and roll

*Revision ID: 1159956168 | Timestamp: 2023-06-13T16:05:15Z*

**Rock and roll** (often written as **rock & roll**, '''rock 'n' roll**, or **rock n roll''') is a [genre](Genre (music)) of [music](popular)(popular music) that evolved in the United States during the late 1940s and early 1950s. It [originated](Origins of rock and roll) from African-American music such as [jazz](jazz), [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues), [boogie-woogie](boogie-woogie), [gospel](gospel music), [blues](jump)(jump blues), as well as [music](country)(country music).Larry Birnbaum, ''Before Elvis: The Prehistory of Rock 'n' Roll'', Scarecrow Press, 2013, p.vii-x. While rock and roll's formative elements can be heard in blues records from the 1920sDavis, Francis. *[History of the Blues](The)(iarchive:historyofblues00davi)* (New York: Hyperion, 1995), . and in country records of the 1930s,Peterson, Richard A. *[Creating Country Music: Fabricating Authenticity](https://books.google.com/books?id=J3zWpIOLB-MC&pg=PA9)* (1999), p. 9, . the genre did not acquire its name until 1954."The Roots of Rock 'n' Roll 1946–1954". 2004. Universal Music Enterprises.

According to journalist [Kot](Greg)(Greg Kot), "rock and roll" refers to a style of popular music originating in the United States in the 1950s. By the mid-1960s, rock and roll had developed into "the more encompassing international style known as [music](rock)(rock music), though the latter also continued to be known in many circles as rock and roll."Kot, Greg, ["Rock and roll"](https://www.britannica.com/art/rock-and-roll-early-style-of-rock-music) , in the *[Britannica](Encyclopædia)(Encyclopædia Britannica)*, published [online](Encyclopædia Britannica Online) 17 June 2008 and also in print and in the *Encyclopædia Britannica Ultimate Reference* DVD; Chicago : Encyclopædia Britannica, 2010 For the purpose of differentiation, this article deals with the first definition.

In the earliest rock and roll styles, either the [piano](piano) or [saxophone](saxophone) was typically the lead instrument. These instruments were generally replaced or supplemented by guitar in the middle to late 1950s. The beat is essentially a dance rhythmBusnar, Gene, It's Rock 'n' Roll: A musical history of the fabulous fifties, Julian Messner, New York, 1979, p. 45 with an accentuated [backbeat](backbeat), almost always provided by a [drum](snare)(snare drum).P. Hurry, M. Phillips, and M. Richards, *Heinemann advanced music* (Heinemann, 2001), pp. 153–4. Classic rock and roll is usually played with one or two [guitar](electric)(electric guitar)s (one [lead](lead guitar), one [rhythm](rhythm guitar)) and a [bass](double)(double bass) (string bass). After the mid-1950s, electric [guitar](bass)(bass guitar)s ("Fender bass") and [kits](drum)(drum kits) became popular in classic rock.S. Evans, "The development of the Blues" in A. F. Moore, ed., *[Cambridge companion to blues and gospel music](The)(Cambridge Companions to Music)* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), pp. 40–42.

Rock and roll had a polarizing influence on lifestyles, fashion, attitudes, and language. It is often portrayed in movies, fan magazines, and on television. Some people believe that the music had a positive influence on the [rights movement](civil)(civil rights movement), because both [American](Black)(Black American) and [American](White)(White American) teenagers enjoyed it.G. C. Altschuler, ''All shook up: how rock 'n' roll changed America'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press US, 2003), p. 35.

**Harvey Phillip Spector** (December 26, 1939January 16, 2021) was an American record producer and songwriter. He is best known for his innovative recording practices in the 1960s and development of the [of Sound](Wall)(Wall of Sound), a production style that is characterized for its diffusion of [color](tone)(tone color)s and dense orchestral sound, which he described as a "[Wagnerian](Richard Wagner)" approach to [and roll](rock)(rock and roll). He is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in [music](pop)(pop music) history and one of the most successful producers of the 1960s. In the 2000s, Spector was [tried for and convicted of murder](was)(Murder of Lana Clarkson) and sentenced to 19 years in prison.

Born in [Bronx](the)(the Bronx), Spector moved to Los Angeles as a teenager and began his career in 1958 as a founding member of [Teddy Bears](the)(the Teddy Bears), for whom he penned "[Know Him Is to Love Him](To)(To Know Him Is to Love Him)", a U.S. number-one hit. In 1960, after working as an apprentice to [and Stoller](Leiber)(Leiber and Stoller), Spector co-founded [Records](Philles)(Philles Records), and at the age of 21 became the youngest ever U.S. label owner to that point. Dubbed the "[Tycoon of Teen](First)(Honorific nicknames in popular music)", (This appears in the microfilm edition of the *Herald Tribune* but apparently not in the online database) Spector came to be considered the first [auteur](auteur) of the music industry for the unprecedented control he had over every phase of the recording process. He produced acts such as [Ronettes](the)(the Ronettes), [Crystals](the)(the Crystals), and [& Tina Turner](Ike)(Ike & Tina Turner), and typically collaborated with arranger [Nitzsche](Jack)(Jack Nitzsche) and engineer [Levine](Larry)(Larry Levine). The musicians from his *de facto* [band](house)(house band), later known as "[Wrecking Crew](the)(the Wrecking Crew (music))", rose to industry fame through his hit records.

In the early 1970s, Spector produced [Beatles](the)(the Beatles)' *[It Be](Let)(Let It Be (Beatles album))* and several solo records by [Lennon](John)(John Lennon) and [Harrison](George)(George Harrison). By the mid-1970s Spector had produced eighteen U.S. Top 10 singles for various artists. His chart-toppers included [Righteous Brothers](the)(the Righteous Brothers)' "[Lost That Lovin' Feelin'](You've)(You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin')", the Beatles' "[Long and Winding Road](The)(The Long and Winding Road)", and Harrison's "[Sweet Lord](My)(My Sweet Lord)". Following one-off productions for [Cohen](Leonard)(Leonard Cohen) (''[of a Ladies' Man](Death)(Death of a Ladies' Man (album))*), [DiMucci](Dion)(Dion DiMucci) (*[to Be with You](Born)(Born to Be with You (album))*), and the [Ramones](Ramones) (*[of the Century](End)(End of the Century)''), Spector remained largely inactive amid a lifestyle of seclusion, drug use, and increasingly erratic behavior.

Spector helped establish the role of the [as an instrument](studio)(Recording studio as an instrument), the integration of [art](pop)(pop art) aesthetics into music ([pop](art)(art pop)), and the genres of [rock](art)(art rock) and [pop](dream)(dream pop). His honors include the 1973 [Award for Album of the Year](Grammy)(Grammy Award for Album of the Year) for co-producing Harrison's *[for Bangladesh](Concert)(The Concert for Bangladesh (album))*, a 1989 induction into the [and Roll Hall of Fame](Rock)(Rock and Roll Hall of Fame), and a 1997 induction into the [Hall of Fame](Songwriters)(Songwriters Hall of Fame). In 2004, Spector was ranked number 63 on *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone)*s list of the [artists in history](greatest)(Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time).See:

*

*  In 2009, after two decades in semi-retirement, he was convicted of the 2003 murder of actress [Clarkson](Lana)(Lana Clarkson) and sentenced to 19 years to life in prison, where he died in 2021.

## Early life

Smit-McPhee was born on 13 June 1996 in [Adelaide](Adelaide), South Australia, the son of Sonja Smit and Andy McPhee. His father is an actor and former professional wrestler. His older sister is actress and singer [Smit-McPhee](Sianoa)(Sianoa Smit-McPhee).

At age 16, Smit-McPhee was diagnosed with [spondylitis](ankylosing)(ankylosing spondylitis), a degenerative form of [arthritis](arthritis) which causes vertebrae in the spine to fuse and can lead to chronic pain and loss of vision. Due to the condition, he is [blind](Blindness) in his left eye.
Ankylosing spondylitis (a degenerative form of arthritis).

The characteristic polynomial is p(λ) = det(A − λI) = det([[2−λ, 1], [1, 2−λ]]) = (2−λ)^2 − 1 = λ^2 − 4λ + 3 = (λ − 1)(λ − 3). The eigenvalues are 1 and 3.

### Origins of the concept and establishment of the term

[[File:British Commonealth of Nations handwritten on Anglo-Irish Treaty draft.png|thumb|upright=1.3|Draft of the 1921 [Treaty](Anglo-Irish)(Anglo-Irish Treaty), with "British Empire" crossed out and "British Commonwealth of Nations" added by hand.]]

[[File:CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|The prime ministers of five members at the 1944 [Prime Ministers' Conference](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference). (L-R) [King](Mackenzie)(William Lyon Mackenzie King) (Canada), [Smuts](Jan)(Jan Smuts) ([Africa](South)(Union of South Africa)), [Churchill](Winston)(Winston Churchill) (United Kingdom), [Fraser](Peter)(Peter Fraser (New Zealand politician)) (New Zealand) and [Curtin](John)(John Curtin) (Australia)]]

[Elizabeth II](Queen)(Queen Elizabeth II), in her address to Canada on [Day](Dominion)(Canada Day) in 1959, pointed out that the [of Canada](Confederation)(Confederation of Canada) on 1 July 1867 had been the birth of the "first independent country within the British Empire". She declared: "So, it also marks the beginning of that free association of independent states which is now known as the Commonwealth of Nations." As long ago as 1884 [Rosebery](Lord)(Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery), while visiting [Australia](Australia), had described the changing British Empire, as some of its colonies became more independent, as a "Commonwealth of Nations". Conferences of British and colonial prime ministers occurred periodically from [first one in 1887](the)(First Colonial Conference), leading to the creation of the [Conference](Imperial)(Imperial Conference)s in 1911.

The Commonwealth developed from the imperial conferences. A specific proposal was presented by [Smuts](Jan)(Jan Smuts) in 1917 when he coined the term "the British Commonwealth of Nations" and envisioned the "future constitutional relations and readjustments in essence" at the [Peace Conference of 1919](Paris)(Paris Peace Conference, 1919), attended by delegates from the Dominions as well as the United Kingdom.F.S. Crafford, *Jan Smuts: A Biography* (2005) p. 142The Irish [of Allegiance](Oath)(Oath of Allegiance (Ireland)), agreed in 1921, included the [Free State](Irish)(Irish Free State)'s "adherence to and membership of the group of nations forming the British Commonwealth of Nations". The term first received imperial statutory recognition in the [Treaty](Anglo-Irish)(Anglo-Irish Treaty) of 1921, when the term *British Commonwealth of Nations* was substituted for *British Empire* in the wording of the oath taken by members of parliament of the [Free State](Irish)(Irish Free State).

### Adoption and formalisation of the Commonwealth

In the [Declaration](Balfour)(Balfour Declaration of 1926) at the [Imperial Conference](1926)(1926 Imperial Conference), the United Kingdom and its dominions agreed they were "equal in status, in no way subordinate one to another in any aspect of their domestic or external affairs, though united by common allegiance to the Crown, and freely associated as members of the British Commonwealth of Nations". The term "[Commonwealth](Commonwealth)" was officially adopted to describe the community.

These aspects to the relationship were formalised by the [of Westminster](Statute)(Statute of Westminster 1931) in 1931, which applied to Canada without the need for ratification, but Australia, [Zealand](New)(New Zealand), and [Newfoundland](Dominion of Newfoundland) had to ratify the statute for it to take effect. Newfoundland never did as due to economic hardship and the need for financial assistance from London, Newfoundland voluntarily accepted the suspension of self-government in 1934 and governance reverted to direct control from London. Newfoundland later joined Canada as its [province](tenth)(Provinces and territories of Canada) in 1949. [Australia](Australia) and New Zealand ratified the Statute in [1942](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942) and [1947](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947) respectively.

Although the Union of South Africa was not among the Dominions that needed to adopt the Statute of Westminster for it to take effect, two laws—the Status of the Union Act, 1934, and the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act of 1934—were passed to confirm South Africa's status as a sovereign state.

## Contracts for marriage

Lady Jane acted as chief mourner at Catherine Parr's funeral; Thomas Seymour showed continued interest to keep her in his household, and she returned there for about two months before he was arrested at the end of 1548. Seymour's brother, the [Protector](Lord)(Lord Protector), [Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset](Edward)(Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset), felt threatened by Thomas' popularity with the young King Edward. Among other things, Thomas Seymour was charged with proposing Jane as a bride for the king.

In the course of Thomas Seymour's following [attainder](attainder) and execution, Jane's father was lucky to stay largely out of trouble. After his fourth interrogation by the [Council](King's)(Privy Council of England), he proposed his daughter Jane as a bride for the Protector's eldest son, [Hertford](Lord)(Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford). Nothing came of this, however, and Jane was not engaged until 25 May 1553, her bridegroom being [Guildford Dudley](Lord)(Lord Guildford Dudley), a younger son of [Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland](John)(John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland). The Duke, [President](Lord)(Lord President of the Council) of the [Council](King's)(privy council) from late 1549, was then the most powerful man in the country. On 25 May 1553, the couple were married at [House](Durham)(Durham House (London)) in a triple wedding, in which Jane's sister [Catherine](Lady Catherine Grey) was matched with the heir of the [of Pembroke](Earl)(William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (1551 creation)), [Herbert](Lord)(Henry Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke), and another [Katherine](Katherine Hastings, Countess of Huntingdon), Lord Guildford's sister, with [Hastings](Henry)(Henry Hastings, 3rd Earl of Huntingdon), the [of Huntingdon](Earl)(Francis Hastings, 2nd Earl of Huntingdon)'s heir.; .
She was married to Guildford Dudley, the younger son of John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland (married on 25 May 1553).

**Emmanuelle Grey Rossum** (born September 12, 1986) is an American actress, director, and singer. She is known for her portrayal of [Gallagher](Fiona)(List of Shameless (American TV series) characters#Fiona Gallagher) in the television series *[Shameless](Shameless (U.S. TV series))* (2011–2021). Since the mid-2010s, she has also directed and produced television, including the 2022 [Peacock](Peacock (streaming service)) series *[Angelyne](Angelyne (miniseries))* in which she also stars.

Born and raised in New York City, she began professionally performing as a child with the [Opera](Metropolitan)(Metropolitan Opera). Early on-screen roles included *[Genius](Genius (1999 film))* (1999), *[Songcatcher](Songcatcher)* (2000), *[Passionada](Passionada)* (2002), and *[Nola](Nola (film))* (2003). At sixteen, she was cast in her breakthrough role in *[River](Mystic)(Mystic River (film))* (2003). Rossum starred in the 2004 sci-fi film *[Day After Tomorrow](The)(The Day After Tomorrow)*, and also received critical acclaim for her performance in the leading role of [Daaé](Christine)(Christine Daaé) in the film adaptation of *[Phantom of the Opera](The)(The Phantom of the Opera (2004 film))* (2004). She is also well known for acting in the films *[Poseidon](Poseidon (film))* (2006), *[Evolution](Dragonball:)(Dragonball Evolution)* (2009), *[Inside](Inside (2011 film))* (2011), *[Creatures](Beautiful)(Beautiful Creatures (2013 film))* (2013), *[Comet](Comet (film))* (2014), ''[Not You](You're)(You're Not You)* (2014), and *[Pursuit](Cold)(Cold Pursuit)* (2019).

In 2007, Rossum released her debut album, *[Out](Inside)(Inside Out (Emmy Rossum album))*. She also released a Christmas [EP](Extended play) the same year, titled *Carol of the Bells*. In 2013, she released a follow-up album called *[Journey](Sentimental)(Sentimental Journey (Emmy Rossum album))''.

## Early life

Emmanuelle Grey Rossum was born on September 12, 1986, in New York City. She is the only child of Cheryl Rossum, a single mother who worked as a corporate photographer. Her parents separated while her mother was pregnant, and as of 2007, she had met her father only twice.

Rossum's mother is Jewish of [Jewish](Russian)(History of the Jews in Russia) descent, and her father is [Protestant](Protestant) of English and Dutch ancestry. Rossum identifies as Jewish and has stated that her mother instilled in her the "Jewish code of ethics and morals". She was named for her great-grandfather, whose first name was Emanuel, using the feminine spelling.

Upon singing "[Birthday](Happy)(Happy Birthday to You)" in all 12 keys,Joffe, Jessica. "Emmy Rossum: Hollywood's newest It Girl." Glamour: September 2006. p 326-7, 392 Rossum was welcomed to join the [Opera](Metropolitan)(Metropolitan Opera) Children's Chorus by chorus director Elena Doria at age seven. Over the course of five years she sang onstage with the chorus and had the chance to perform with singers such as [Domingo](Plácido)(Plácido Domingo) and [Pavarotti](Luciano)(Luciano Pavarotti). For anywhere from $5 to $10 a night, Rossum sang in six languages in 20 operas, including *[bohème](La)(La bohème)*, *[Turandot](Turandot)*, a [Hall](Carnegie)(Carnegie Hall) presentation of *[damnation de Faust](La)(La damnation de Faust)*, and ''[ A Midsummer Night's Dream](A Midsummer Night's Dream (opera) )''."It's Evening in America". *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*. May 2012. Page 152. She also worked under the direction of [Zeffirelli](Franco)(Franco Zeffirelli) in *[Carmen](Carmen)*.

An increasing interest in pursuing acting led to taking classes with Flo Salant Greenberg of [New Actors Workshop](The)(The New Actors Workshop) in New York City. She has also worked with acting coach Terry Knickerbocker.

Rossum attended the [School](Spence)(Spence School), a private school in [Manhattan](Manhattan), before dropping out to pursue career opportunities. She received her high school diploma at fifteen years old via online-extension courses offered by [University](Stanford)(Stanford University)'s [Program for Gifted Youth](Education)(Education Program for Gifted Youth) (EPGY). She enrolled at [University](Columbia)(Columbia University), studying French, art history and philosophy.
Columbia University.

**Gordon Granger** (November 6, 1821 – January 10, 1876) was a career U.S. Army officer and a [Union](Union (American Civil War)) general during the [Civil War](American)(American Civil War), where he distinguished himself at the [of Chickamauga](Battle)(Battle of Chickamauga).

Granger is best remembered for his part in the [of Chickamauga](Battle)(Battle of Chickamauga) and the [of Chattanooga](Battle)(Battle of Chattanooga III) and for issuing [Order No. 3](General)(General Order No. 3) on June 19, 1865, in [Texas](Galveston,)(Galveston, Texas), further informing residents of, and enforcing, [Lincoln](Abraham)(Abraham Lincoln)'s [Proclamation](Emancipation)(Emancipation Proclamation) which set all Confederate states' slaves free on January 1, 1863. June 19 is now commemorated by the federal holiday of [Juneteenth](Juneteenth).
Major General Gordon Granger of the Union Army.

The actual pronunciation in [Arabic](Literary)(Modern Standard Arabic) varies regionally. The first vowel varies from  to , while the second vowel varies from  to  to . For example, the pronunciation in Egypt is  and in Central East Arabia . |group=lower-roman}} 'the recitation'), also romanized '''Qur'an** or **Koran**, The form **Koran** was most predominant from the second half of the 18th century till the 1980s, when it has been superseded by either **Qur'an** or **Quran'*. Other transliterations include *al-Coran*, *Coran*, *Kuran* and *al-Qur'an*. The adjectives vary as well and include *Koranic*, *Quranic* and *Qur'anic'' (sometimes in lowercase).

|group=lower-roman}} is the central [text](religious)(religious text) of [Islam](Islam), believed by [Muslim](Muslim)s to be a [revelation](revelation in Islam) from [God](God in Islam). It is organized in 114 [chapters](surah) (pl.:  , sing.:  ), which consist of [verses](āyah) (pl.:  , sing.:  , [cons.](construct case): ). In addition to its religious significance, it is widely regarded as the finest work in [literature](Arabic)(Arabic literature), and has significantly influenced the [language](Arabic)(Arabic language).

Muslims believe that the Quran was orally revealed by God to the [prophet](final)(Khatam an-Nabiyyin), [Muhammad](Muhammad in Islam), through the archangel [Gabriel](Gabriel) incrementally over a period of some 23 years, beginning on [Al Qadr](Laylat)(Night of Power),[Quran 97:1-5](https://quran.com/97) when Muhammad was 40; and concluding in 632, the year of his death. Muslims regard the Quran as Muhammad's most important [miracle](miracle), a proof of his [prophethood](prophethood); and the culmination of a series of divine messages starting with those revealed to [Adam](Adam in Islam), including the [Tawrat](Tawrat), the [Zabur](Zabur) ([Psalms](Psalms)) and the [Injil](Injil) (Gospel). The word *Quran* occurs some 70 times in the text itself, and other names and words are also said to refer to the Quran.

The Quran is believed by Muslims to be not simply divinely inspired, but the literal [of God](word)(Biblical inspiration). Muhammad did not write it as he did not know how to write. In Muslim theology, the Qur'an is considered to be either "[created](Quranic createdness)" or "uncreated".[*Ibn Ḥanbal and the Miḥna*, 1897](Patton,)(#WMP1897): p.54 According to tradition, several of Muhammad's [companions](Companions of the Prophet) served as scribes, recording the revelations. Shortly after the prophet's death, the Quran was compiled by the companions, who had written down or memorized parts of it. Caliph [Uthman](Uthman) established a standard version, now known as the [codex](Uthmanic)(Uthmanic codex), which is generally considered the archetype of the Quran known today. There are, however, [readings](variant)(Qiraʼat), with mostly minor differences in meaning.

The Quran assumes [with major narratives](familiarity)(Biblical and Quranic narratives) recounted in the [Biblical](Books of the Bible) and [scriptures](apocryphal)(Apocrypha). It summarizes some, dwells at length on others and, in some cases, presents alternative accounts and interpretations of events. The Quran describes itself as a book of guidance for humankind ( ). It sometimes offers detailed accounts of specific historical events, and it often emphasizes the moral significance of an event over its narrative sequence. Supplementing the Quran with explanations for some cryptic Quranic narratives, and rulings that also provide the basis for Islamic law in most denominations of Islam, are *[hadith](hadith)s*—oral and written traditions believed to describe words and actions of Muhammad.  During prayers, the Quran is recited only in [Arabic](Arabic).

Someone who has memorized the entire Quran is called a *[hafiz](Hafiz (Quran))*. Ideally, verses are recited with a special kind of [prosody](Prosody (linguistics)) reserved for this purpose, called *[tajwid](tajwid)*. During the month of Ramadan, Muslims typically complete the recitation of the whole Quran during *[tarawih](tarawih)* prayers. In order to extrapolate the meaning of a particular Quranic verse, Muslims rely on [exegesis](exegesis), or commentary rather than a direct translation of the text.

## Trial and execution

Referred to by the court as Jane Dudley, wife of Guildford, Jane was charged with [treason](high)(high treason), as were her husband, two of his brothers, and the former [of Canterbury](archbishop)(archbishop of Canterbury), [Cranmer](Thomas)(Thomas Cranmer). Their trial, by a special commission, took place on 13 November 1553, at [Guildhall](Guildhall, London) in the [of London](City)(City of London). The commission was chaired by [Thomas White](Sir)(Thomas White (merchant)), [Mayor of London](Lord)(Lord Mayor of London), and [Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk](Thomas)(Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk). Other members included [Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby](Edward)(Edward Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby), and [Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath](John)(John Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath). As was to be expected, all defendants were found guilty and sentenced to death. Jane's guilt, of having treacherously assumed the title and the power of the monarch, was evidenced by a number of documents she had signed as "Jane the Quene". Her sentence was to "be burned alive on [Hill](Tower)(Tower Hill) or beheaded as the Queen pleases" ([burning](Execution by burning#Historical usage) was the [English punishment](traditional)(Burning of women in England) for [treason](treason) committed by women).;  The [ambassador](imperial)(List of ambassadors of the Holy Roman Empire to England) reported to [V, Holy Roman Emperor](Charles)(Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor), that her life was to be spared.

[[File:Lady Jane Grey letter as Queen.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Official letter of Lady Jane Grey signing herself as "Jane the Quene". [Temple Library](Inner)(Inner Temple Library), London]]

[rebellion](Wyatt's)(Wyatt's rebellion) in January 1554 against [Mary's marriage plans](Queen)(wedding of Mary I of England and Philip of Spain) with [of Spain](Philip)(Philip II of Spain) sealed Jane's fate. Her father, Henry Grey, 1st Duke of Suffolk, and his two brothers joined the rebellion, and so the government decided to go through with the verdict against Jane and Guildford. Their execution was first scheduled for 9 February 1554, but was then postponed for three days to give Jane a chance to convert to the Catholic faith. Mary sent her chaplain [Feckenham](John)(John Feckenham) to Jane, who was initially not pleased about this. Though she would not give in to his efforts "to save her soul", she became friends with him and allowed him to accompany her to the scaffold.

On the morning of 12 February 1554, the authorities took Guildford from his rooms at the Tower of London to the public [execution](execution) place at Tower Hill, where he was beheaded. A horse and cart brought his remains back to the Tower, past the rooms where Jane was staying. Seeing her husband's corpse return, Jane is reported to have exclaimed: "Oh, Guildford, Guildford." She was then taken out to [Green](Tower)(Tower Green), inside the Tower, to be beheaded. According to the account of her execution given in the anonymous *Chronicle of Queen Jane and of Two Years of Queen Mary*, which formed the basis for [Holinshed](Raphael)(Raphael Holinshed)'s depiction, Jane gave a speech upon ascending the scaffold:

Good people, I am come hither to die, and by a law I am condemned to the same. The fact, indeed, against the Queen's highness was unlawful, and the consenting thereunto by me: but touching the procurement and desire thereof by me or on my behalf, I do wash my hands thereof in innocency, before God, and the face of you, good Christian people, this day.

While admitting to action considered unlawful, she declared that "I do wash my hands thereof in innocence". Jane then recited [51](Psalm)(Psalm 51) (*Have mercy upon me, O God*) in English, and handed her gloves and handkerchief to her maid. The executioner asked her forgiveness, which she granted him, pleading: "I pray you dispatch me quickly." Referring to her head, she asked, "Will you take it off before I lay me down?", and the axeman answered: "No, madam." She then blindfolded herself. Jane then failed to find the block with her hands, and cried, "What shall I do? Where is it?" Probably [Thomas Brydges](Sir)(Thomas Brydges), the Deputy Lieutenant of the Tower, helped her find her way. With her head on the block, Jane spoke the last words of Jesus as recounted by [Luke](Gospel of Luke): "Lord, into thy hands I commend my spirit!" The axe then fell and Jane was beheaded in one clean stroke.

Jane and Guildford are buried in the Chapel of [Peter ad Vincula](St)(Church of St Peter ad Vincula) on the north side of Tower Green. No memorial stone was erected at their grave. Jane's father, the Duke of Suffolk, was executed 11 days after Jane, on 23 February 1554. Her mother, the Duchess of Suffolk, married her Master of the Horse and [chamberlain](Chamberlain (office)), [Stokes](Adrian)(Adrian Stokes (Master of Horse)), in March 1555. She was fully pardoned by Mary and allowed to live at Court with her two surviving daughters. She died in 1559.
The Tower of London. She was held there (in the Tower) before being brought to Tower Green for execution.

## Early life

Jeff Bauman was born on January 2, 1986, and is the son of Jeff Bauman, Sr. and Patty Bauman. Jeff Bauman became engaged to his fiancée Erin Hurley in February 2014 and they married in November 2014. Their daughter, Nora Gail Bauman, was born on July 13, 2014. He worked in the service deli at [Costco](Costco) for three years before the bombing; he returned to his job a year after the blast in June 2014.

# The Fifth Element

*Revision ID: 1157413696 | Timestamp: 2023-05-28T12:33:06Z*

---

| director       = [Besson](Luc)(Luc Besson)

| producer       = [Ledoux](Patrice)(Patrice Ledoux)

| screenplay     =

| story          = Luc Besson

| starring       =

| music          = [Serra](Éric)(Éric Serra)

| cinematography = [Arbogast](Thierry)(Thierry Arbogast)

| editing        = Sylvie Landra

| studio         = [Gaumont](Gaumont Film Company)

| distributor    = Gaumont[Vista International](Buena)(Buena Vista International)

| released       =

| runtime        = 126 minutes

| country        = France

| language       = English

| budget         = US$90 millionmillion and $100million. The most frequently cited figure and also the figure cited by Besson in his book, *The Story of The Fifth Element* is $90million.}}

| gross          = $263.9 million

}}

***The Fifth Element***}} is a 1997 English-language French [fiction](science)(Science fiction film) [film](action)(action film) conceived and directed by [Besson](Luc)(Luc Besson), as well as co-written by Besson and [Mark Kamen](Robert)(Robert Mark Kamen). It stars [Willis](Bruce)(Bruce Willis), [Oldman](Gary)(Gary Oldman), [Holm](Ian)(Ian Holm), [Jovovich](Milla)(Milla Jovovich), and [Tucker](Chris)(Chris Tucker). Primarily set in the 23rd century, the film's central plot involves the survival of planet Earth, which becomes the responsibility of Korben Dallas (Willis), a taxicab driver and former [forces](special)(special forces) major, after a young woman (Jovovich) falls into his cab. To accomplish this, Dallas joins forces with her to recover four mystical stones essential for the defence of Earth against the impending attack of a malevolent cosmic entity.

Besson started writing the story that was developed as *The Fifth Element* when he was 16 years old; he was 38 when the film opened in cinemas. Besson wanted to shoot the film in France, but suitable facilities could not be found; filming took place in [London](London) and [Mauritania](Mauritania) instead. He hired comic artists ["Moebius" Giraud](Jean)(Jean Giraud) and [Mézières](Jean-Claude)(Jean-Claude Mézières), whose books inspired parts of the film, for production design. Costume design was by [Gaultier](Jean-Paul)(Jean-Paul Gaultier).

*The Fifth Element* received mainly positive reviews, although some critics were highly negative. The film won in categories at the [Academy Film Award](British)(51st British Academy Film Awards)s, the [Award](César)(23rd César Awards)s, the [Film Festival](Cannes)(Cannes Film Festival), and the [Award](Lumières)(Lumières Award)s, but also received nominations at the [Raspberry](Golden)(18th Golden Raspberry Awards) and [Bad Movie Award](Stinkers)(1997 Stinkers Bad Movie Awards)s. *The Fifth Element* was a strong financial success, earning more than US$263million at the box office on a $90million budget. At the time of its release, it was the most expensive European film ever made, and it remained the highest-grossing French film at the international box office until the release of *[Intouchables](The)(The Intouchables)* in 2011.
Luc Besson.

## Personal life

On October 15, 2022, Siragusa revealed on-stream that she had been married for several years, after her stream was interrupted by her husband, who could be heard verbally abusing her live on stream. Siragusa alleged that her husband controls her finances, coerced her to stream more than she was willing to, and threatened to kill her dogs if she did not obey his demands. A few days following the incident, Siragusa stated she was seeking legal and emotional counsel, had regained access to her finances and that her husband was out of her life and is seeking help.
Kaitlyn Siragusa.

**John Mark Galecki** (born April 30, 1975) is an American actor. He played [Hofstadter](Leonard)(Leonard Hofstadter) in the [CBS](CBS) sitcom *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)* (2007–2019) for which he received a [Emmy Award](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award) nomination, and [Healy](David)(List of Roseanne and The Conners characters#David Healy) in the [ABC](American Broadcasting Company) sitcoms *[Roseanne](Roseanne)* (1992–1997; 2018) and *[Conners](The)(The Conners)* (2018–2019). Galecki also appeared in the films *[Prancer](Prancer (film))* (1989), ''[Lampoon's Christmas Vacation](National)(National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation)* (1989), *[Kings](Suicide)(Suicide Kings)* (1997), *[Know What You Did Last Summer](I)(I Know What You Did Last Summer)* (1997), *[Bookies](Bookies (film))* (2003), *[Time](In)(In Time)* (2011), and *[Rings](Rings (2017 film))* (2017).

Galecki was one of the highest paid television actors in the world, with his role in *The Big Bang Theory'' earning him approximately US$900,000 per episode between 2017 and 2019. In 2018, he was estimated to be the world's second highest-paid male TV actor by *[Forbes](Forbes)* (behind only his *The Big Bang Theory* co-star [Parsons](Jim)(Jim Parsons)), earning $25 million.

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.

## Giordano Bruno

In his work titled *Essays upon the Mathematics of Mordente: One Hundred and Sixty Articles against the Mathematicians and Philosophers of this Age* (Prague: 1588), Italian philosopher, cosmological theorist, and Hermetic occultist [Bruno](Giordano)(Giordano Bruno) used the unicursal hexagram symbol to represent *Figura Amoris* ("figure of love") part of the [Trinity](Hermetic)(Hermetic Trinity) in his mathesis.
Giordano Bruno. He used the unicursal hexagram to symbolize Figura Amoris as part of the Hermetic Trinity in his mathesis (Essays upon the Mathematics of Mordente, 1588).

#### Hong Taiji

Nurhaci died in 1626, and was succeeded by his eighth son, [Taiji](Hong)(Hong Taiji). Although Hong Taiji was an experienced leader and the commander of two Banners, the Jurchens suffered defeat in 1627, in part due to the Ming's newly acquired Portuguese cannons. To redress the technological and numerical disparity, Hong Taiji in 1634 created his own artillery corps from his existing Han troops, who cast their own cannons in the European design with the help of defector Chinese metallurgists. One of the defining events of Hong Taiji's reign was the official adoption of the name "Manchu" for the united Jurchen people in November 1635. In 1635, the Manchus' Mongol allies were fully incorporated into a separate Banner hierarchy under direct Manchu command. In April 1636, [nobility](Mongol)(Mongolian nobility) of Inner Mongolia, Manchu nobility and the [mandarin](Han)(Mandarin (bureaucrat)) recommended that Hong as the khan of Later Jin should be the emperor of the Great Qing.Tumen jalafun jecen akū: Manchu studies in honour of Giovanni Stary By Giovanni Stary, Alessandra Pozzi, Juha Antero Janhunen, Michael Weiers When he was presented with the [seal](imperial)(Imperial Seal of China) of the Yuan dynasty after the defeat of the last [Khagan](Khagan) of the Mongols, Hong Taiji renamed his state from "Great Jin" to "Great Qing" and elevated his position from Khan to [Emperor](Emperor of China), suggesting imperial ambitions beyond unifying the Manchu territories. Hong Taiji then proceeded to [Korea](invade)(Second Manchu invasion of Korea) again in 1636.

[[File:Sura han ni chiha. Currency of the farther East. No.850.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|*Sura han ni chiha* (Coins of [Khan](Tiancong)(Hong Taiji)) in [alphabet](Manchu)(Manchu alphabet)]]

Meanwhile, Hong Taiji set up a rudimentary bureaucratic system based on the Ming model. He established six boards or executive level ministries in 1631 to oversee finance, personnel, rites, military, punishments, and public works. However, these administrative organs had very little role initially, and it was not until the eve of completing the conquest ten years later that they fulfilled their government roles.

Hong Taiji staffed his bureaucracy with many Han Chinese, including newly surrendered Ming officials, but ensured Manchu dominance by an ethnic quota for top appointments. Hong Taiji's reign also saw a fundamental change of policy towards his Han Chinese subjects. Nurhaci had treated Han in Liaodong according to how much grain they had: those with less than 5 to 7 sin were treated badly, while those with more were rewarded with property. Due to a Han revolt in 1623, Nurhaci turned against them and ordered that they no longer be trusted and enacted discriminatory policies and killings against them. He ordered that Han who assimilated to the Jurchen (in Jilin) before 1619 be treated equally with Jurchens, not like the conquered Han in Liaodong. Hong Taiji recognized the need to attract Han Chinese, explaining to reluctant Manchus why he needed to treat the Ming defector General [Chengchou](Hong)(Hong Chengchou) leniently. Hong Taiji incorporated Han into the Jurchen "nation" as full (if not first-class) citizens, obligated to provide military service. By 1648, less than one-sixth of the bannermen were of Manchu ancestry.
Hong Taiji, Nurhaci’s son, proclaimed the Qing dynasty in 1636 (renaming Great Jin to Great Qing and becoming its emperor).
